Flexible drawdown
Your pension fund is invested, and you draw an income directly from the fund when you want to.
Advantages
Flexibility - you can take income as and when you need it
This feature may be useful for tax planning
Your pension fund can be used by your family after you are gone
Disadvantages
Your fund is exposed to investment and risk and you could run out of money
Your fund will need to be managed by an advisor
There are likely to be ongoing fees
Paula has built up a pension fund from several different jobs and now wants to stop working. Her husband Michael intends to continue working as a cabinet maker for the next 5 to 10 years, although his earnings vary each year depending on demand for his work. During a good year his earnings can easily support them both.

By taking her fund by flexible drawdown, Paula can take as much income as she needs to supplement the couple's income during Michael's low-income years. During his higher income years, she can take no income, leaving her fund invested. When Michael decides to retire in the future, she can increase her income to a higher level, or decide to buy an annuity.
If you need your income to last longer - what are your options?
  • You could increase your pension contributions before you retire
  • You could start to draw an income later
  • You could reduce your retirement income
  • You could take more risk with your investments in the hope you receive higher returns
Death benefits
One of the advantages of flexible drawdown is that on your death your fund is available to your loved ones. What would they receive?
  • If you are over 75 when you die, your loved ones pay tax on withdrawals at their own rate
  • Or they can leave the fund invested
